questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A company is evaluating the licenses that are available in Microsoft 365.
The company needs to minimize licensing costs.
Match each license to its requirement. To answer, drag the appropriate license from the column on the left to its requirement on the right. Each license may be used once, more than once, or not at all.
NOTE: Each correct match is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The answer is correct.
1. F3 is the cheapest, 8$. Only mobile apps needed.
2. BP is the cheapest, 22$. Desktop apps needed.
3. E3 is the cheapest, 36$. Windows 10 needed.
4. E5 is only possible, 57$. Phone system needed.
Istg these questions are pissing me off all these license questions. How are you possibly supposed to remember all these?!?!

I think I get it for the second question why it's BP and not F3. Here what is included in BP:

Web and mobile versions of Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and Outlook (mobile version of outlook)

F3 does not include Outlook mobile app and will use Office for Web to get to mailbox. There is a subtle difference between question 1 and 2

comments.content:
now a free addon with E3 since March 2022
https://www.quexcel.com/knowledge-base/knowledge-base/no-longer-additional-cost-for-microsoft-teams-audio-conferencing/

discussion.content:
F3 is 8$/user/month
BP is 22$/user/month
BP includes desktop apps (question 2 mentions Outlook)
F3 includes Office for Web and mobile apps only
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compare-microsoft-365-enterprise-plans#coreui-contentrichblock-5h0307m

Phone System, Audio Conferencing is only with E5
E3 is cheaper than Business Premium

Key word is, minimize the cost.

So 
1. F3
2. F3
3. E3
4. E5

comments.content:
"Regarding the F3 licensing: You CANNOT use a desktop mail client to connect. You will have to use a web or mobile client."
Not from MS official site*

When you look at the comparison table for F3 it lists 'outlook' but there is a superscript that states the following;
F3 includes Office for Web and mobile apps only. Office mobile limited to devices with integrated screens 10.1” diagonally or less”.
F3 includes 2GB inbox only, No Outlook Integration, no Voicemail.

https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/compare-microsoft-365-enterprise-plans#coreui-contentrichblock-5h0307m

The question doesn't specify 'desktop' apps.
It says 'office web and mobile apps'
These ARE included in F3 along with outlook web and 'Windows 11 Enterprise E3'
Currently available frontline plans are Microsoft 365 F1/MS 365 F3 and Office 365 F3
F3 does NOT come with desktop apps.

https://www.microsoft.com/nb-no/microsoft-365/enterprise/f3?market=no

F3 gives both outlook, app and webapplications.

E3 - Gives all that plus Windows 10 Enterprise
E5 - gives everything in E3 + Conference call + some security capabilities.

BP is also cheaper that e3 and e5, but only provides Windows 10 Pro. Also more expensive that F3. go for the minimizing cost.

discussion.content: Business edition is for company with less 300 employees ....no ?
is correct. M365 BP contain Windows 10 Business

questions.question_text:
A company deploys Microsoft 365.
You must implement conditional access to restrict access to administrative accounts when users authenticate from specific locations.
You need to select the lowest cost license that meets the requirement.
Which license should you choose?

discussion.content: Link provided supports A as the answer

Selected Answer: A
Correct
https://www.microsoft.com/fr-be/security/business/microsoft-entra-pricing?market=be

Answer: A 

To meet the requirement of implementing conditional access to restrict access to administrative accounts when users authenticate from specific locations, you need to choose the Azure Active Directory Premium P1 license. This license includes the conditional access feature which allows you to control access to resources based on specific conditions, including location. 

The Azure Active Directory Premium P2 license includes additional advanced identity protection features, but they are not required to meet this specific requirement. 

The Azure Active Directory Free and Azure Active Directory B2B licenses do not include the conditional access feature.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/authentication/concept-mfa-licensing#available-versions-of-azure-ad-multi-factor-authentication

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
A is correct. Lowest cost license that meets the requirement = P1

P2 is correct
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/business/identity-access-management/azure-ad-pricing?msclkid=4e6c2b1cca2011ec977822dedfa0cd9b

Selected Answer: A
P1, A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/overview
Using this feature requires an Azure AD Premium P1 license. 
A

Selected Answer: A
Link in answer supports A as answer, CA supports IP location under P1

comments.content:
It looks like its P1

"Many organizations have common access concerns that Conditional Access policies can help with such as:
Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles"

"Using this feature requires an Azure AD Premium P1 license"

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/overview
no you are mixing up the requirements with regards to admin accounts, it's not about PIM here
yup. I agreed. I mean if this is related to an admin account - conditional access, then the correct answer should be P2, since this will need PIM feature which only P2 have!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
they are featurer of Priviledged identity management, so P2

questions.question_text:
Your company plans to purchase a Microsoft 365 subscription.
The company requires intranet and team sites.
You need to select a Microsoft 365 subscription that provides the required features.
Which two subscriptions can you use? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
The names listed are the old names, current names used are:
Microsoft 365 Business Basic (formerly Office 365 Business Essentials)
Microsoft 365 Business Standard (formerly Office 365 Business Premium)
Microsoft 365 Business Premium (formerly Microsoft 365 Business)

What does confuse me is that all three support intranet (SharePoint) and Teams. So except for the Home version all three can be used. Makes sense to select the cheapest options, but thats not mentioned in the question.

comments.content: Office 365 Business does not exist. So that could be a reason why C is wrong.
wrong, the screenshot does show Office 365 Business (old name), on the right, does not have Sharepoint and Teams. I looked at the wrong column.

went to the way back machine and here is a capture of the features from 2020, it does look like the 3 would be correct:
https://web.archive.org/web/20200422094542/https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/compare-all-microsoft-365-products?activetab=tab:primaryr2
perhaps under the old names, it was not the case, we'd have to find the comparison table from back then
So B and D

I'm not realy sure but the product Office 365 Business doesn't never exist. It allways was namend Microsoft 365 Business. See product name "formerly" https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/compare-all-microsoft-365-products?activetab=tab:primaryr2

So if this question comes on the exam
They need to rephrase this question with the latest update

Microsoft 365 Business Basic (formerly Office 365 Business Essentials)

Create team sites to share information, content, and files throughout your intranet using SharePoint

https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/business/compare-all-microsoft-365-business-products?activetab=tab:primaryr2

discussion.content: To read the choices correctly, B is Office Business Premium, not O365 Business Premium, which makes it different. For this reason I think C and D are the correct answers.

It is not O365 Business premium but O365 BUsiness which is mentioned at answer C. 
O365 Business (now M365 Apss for Bus.) does not include exchange and teams.

discussion.content:
This is a better source for the answer:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/admin/contact-support-for-business-products?view=o365-worldwide&tabs=online

Answer: D

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/admin/contact-support-for-business-products?view=o365-worldwide&tabs=online

Go to the admin center at https://admin.microsoft.com. If you get a message that says you don't have permission to access this page or perform this action, you aren't an admin. For more information, see Who has admin permissions in my business?.

Keyword = don't have permission to access this page
Permission = Roles
Answer: D

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide:
"If you get a message in the admin center telling you that you don't have permissions to edit a setting or page, it's because you are assigned a role that doesn't have that permission"

Answer is D
Correct D

Must be either a Global admin, or a service support admin
Ans. is most likely D
D is correct

choices.D: Your account is not a member of the global admin role
choices.C: Your company does not have Premier support

questions.question_text:
You use Microsoft Business Products.
When you try to create a support request, you receive the following message:
You don't have permission to access this page or perform this action.
You need to determine the cause of the error message.
What is the cause?

discussion.content:
Regarding 30-day trial... answer is YES.
link: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/partner-center/offer-your-customers-trials-of-microsoft-products

CSP can provide 30-day trial licenses to customers. Ans: YES

3 Answers YES to all

Statement 1: Yes
Statement 2: Yes
Statement 3: No

Regaring last one: No, that statement is not entirely accurate. Cloud Solution Providers (CSPs) can charge customers for licenses based on various models, including per-user/per-month pricing or based on the type and quantity of licenses purchased. While CSPs can offer flexible billing options and often have the ability to adjust license allocations based on customer needs, they are not strictly limited to charging only for licenses that customers use. They may offer subscription-based plans that include a set number of licenses regardless of whether all licenses are actively used by customers.

Y, Y and N!
Pay for all licenses using or not..

Y, Y and N!
If you buy 10 license but have 8 users You will use 8 license but You will pay for 10 licenses!

If a user is on maternity leave and the 365 license is still assigned to a user, the company still needs to pay for the license at the end of the billing term.

Y
Y
N
If the question is Can Only then the third option MUST be NO. TIP! Read the question carefully guys (5 times if you must) so that you don't miss key words.

comments.content: exactly, is can not only so No

discussion.content:
I think the third part is to do with "license-based, usage-based, and one-time purchases". So the answer would be no
The license-based price list is updated monthly, and Microsoft releases new pricing 30 days before it takes effect. Examples of license-based services include Office 365
Usage-based pricing is dynamic and changes frequently. Examples of usage-based services include Microsoft Azure.
One-time purchase pricing is also dynamic. Examples of one-time purchases include Microsoft Azure reservations 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/partner-center/csp-documents-and-learning-resources

NYN - WHY? 
Billing is monthly 
30-day trial - no problem
can only charge customers for lics that customers USE - who know if you use or no lics?
